title: Tarnanthi: Festival of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art
text:
The work of more than 1000 indigenous artists will be featured at the Art Gallery of South Australia and other venues from October 18-January 27.

What: The work of more than 1000 artists from around Australia in exhibitions at the Art Gallery of South Australia (AGSA) and venues across South Australia, plus an art fair.

Gallery director Rhana Devenport says: "Visitors will experience 63 collaborative or solo projects, 30 presented at AGSA and another 33 partner venues, as well as an abundance of publicly accessible events."

Blood Money – Infinite Dollar Note – Dundalli, Commemorative, 2018 by Ryan Presley. Carl Warner

The artists range in age from 15 to 81. Their works include paintings, photographs, prints, carvings, sculptures, moving images, works on paper, textiles and performances.

A highlight over the opening weekend is the annual Tarnanthi Art Fair at Tandanya National Aboriginal Cultural Institute. All proceeds from sales go directly to the artists and art centres. The event is also an opportunity to meet artists.

A full program of public events, artist talks and performances will be open to the public on the opening weekend. Exclusively at AGSA, Ryan Presley’s Blood Money Currency Exchange Terminal will offer visitors the opportunity to exchange Australian dollars (AUD) for various denominations of limited-edition Blood Money Dollars (BMD). Based on Presley’s series of watercolour paintings, money raised will go to Aboriginal youth programs and exchange rates may fluctuate.
description: The work of more than 1000 indigenous artists will be featured at the Art Gallery of South Australia and other venues from October 18-January 27.
